## Time series data

  - Four-yearly Olympic winning times
  - Annual Google profits
  - Quarterly Australian beer production
  - Monthly rainfall
  - Weekly retail sales
  - Daily IBM stock prices
  - Hourly electricity demand
  - 5-minute freeway traffic counts
  - Time-stamped stock transaction data

## Class packages
\fontsize{13}{14}\sf

```r
# Data manipulation and plotting functions
library(tidyverse)
# Time series manipulation
library(tsibble)
# Forecasting functions
library(fable)
# Time series graphics and statistics
library(feasts)
# Tidy time series data
library(tsibbledata)
```

\pause


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/unnamed-chunk-1_67975638c0ad91d76304d60829320455'}

```{.r .cell-code}
# All of the above and more
library(fpp3)
```
:::

## `tsibble` objects

* A `tsibble` allows storage and manipulation of multiple time series in R.

* It contains:

  + An index: time information about the observation
  + Measured variable(s): numbers of interest
  + Key variable(s): optional unique identifiers for each series

* It works with tidyverse functions.

## The `tsibble` index

### Example
\fontsize{11}{12}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/tstable_f37f5ee4eeabc6747b8ae083c93d01b7'}

```{.r .cell-code}
mydata <- tsibble(
  year = 2012:2016,
  y = c(123, 39, 78, 52, 110),
  index = year
)
mydata
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tsibble: 5 x 2 [1Y]
   year     y
  <int> <dbl>
1  2012   123
2  2013    39
3  2014    78
4  2015    52
5  2016   110
```
:::
:::


## The `tsibble` index

\begin{block}{}
For observations more frequent than once per year, we need to use a time class function on the index.
\end{block}
\fontsize{12}{13}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/tstablemonth_63c3ac3b7f92e328dfdaf8e762a5a40d'}

:::

::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/tstablemonth2_0c69d603db8b44fe4df258949da19c0f'}

```{.r .cell-code}
z
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 5 x 2
  Month    Observation
  <chr>          <dbl>
1 2019 Jan          50
2 2019 Feb          23
3 2019 Mar          34
4 2019 Apr          30
5 2019 May          25
```
:::
:::


## The `tsibble` index

\begin{block}{}
For observations more frequent than once per year, we need to use a time class function on the index.
\end{block}
\fontsize{12}{13}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/month-tsibble_df41ea0005ab22d0d74c77b8c2377622'}

```{.r .cell-code}
z |>
  mutate(Month = yearmonth(Month)) |>
  as_tsibble(index = Month)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tsibble: 5 x 2 [1M]
     Month Observation
     <mth>       <dbl>
1 2019 Jan          50
2 2019 Feb          23
3 2019 Mar          34
4 2019 Apr          30
5 2019 May          25
```
:::
:::


## The `tsibble` index

Common time index variables can be created with these functions:

###

::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/tstable2_ec8d791e9eef299a1856fcd6b81c6d17'}
::: {.cell-output-display}
|Frequency |Function             |
|:---------|:--------------------|
|Annual    |`start:end`          |
|Quarterly |`yearquarter()`      |
|Monthly   |`yearmonth()`        |
|Weekly    |`yearweek()`         |
|Daily     |`as_date()`, `ymd()` |
|Sub-daily |`as_datetime()`      |
:::
:::


# Example: Australian prison population

## Australian prison population

\full{Beechworth_prison}

## Read a csv file and convert to a tsibble {-}
\fontsize{10}{11}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/prison_0aada2e839e0289fe3cd9670313a6e24'}

```{.r .cell-code}
prison <- readr::read_csv("data/prison_population.csv")
```

## Read a csv file and convert to a tsibble {-}
\fontsize{10}{11}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/prison5_2cb0cc64e0eb651a26f2445fae49a48c'}

```{.r .cell-code}
prison <- readr::read_csv("data/prison_population.csv") |>
  mutate(Quarter = yearquarter(date)) |>
  select(-date) |>
  as_tsibble(
    index = Quarter,
    key = c(state, gender, legal, indigenous)
  )
```

# Example: Australian pharmaceutical sales

## Australian Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme

\full{pills}

## Australian Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
\begin{block}{}
The \alert{Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme} (PBS) is the Australian government drugs subsidy scheme.
\end{block}
\pause\fontsize{13.3}{15}\sf

  * Many drugs bought from pharmacies are subsidised to allow more equitable access to modern drugs.
  * The cost to government is determined by the number and types of drugs purchased. Currently nearly 1\% of GDP.
  * The total cost is budgeted based on forecasts of drug usage.
  * Costs are disaggregated by drug type (ATC1 x15 / ATC2 84), concession category (x2) and patient type (x2), giving $84\times2\times2=336$ time series.

## Working with `tsibble` objects {-}
\fontsize{8}{10}\sf




::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/pbs1_294b927b4aba822265960c1a1edfc37a'}

## Working with `tsibble` objects {-}
\fontsize{12}{14}\sf

We can use the `filter()` function to select rows.

\fontsize{8}{10}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/pbs2_6741b21276fa9e1aa38c3a6959bd29ee'}

```{.r .cell-code}
PBS |>
  filter(ATC2 == "A10")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```

# Key:       Concession, Type, ATC1, ATC2 [4]

      <mth> <chr>        <chr>  <chr> <chr>     <chr> <chr>       <dbl>  <dbl>
 1 1991 Jul Concessional Co-pa~ A     Alimenta~ A10   ANTIDIAB~   89733 2.09e6
```

## Working with `tsibble` objects {-}
\fontsize{12}{14}\sf

We can use the `select()` function to select columns.

\fontsize{8}{10}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/pbs3_9f308141a5f20b6303086ed8eea21a31'}

```{.r .cell-code}
PBS |>
  filter(ATC2 == "A10") |>
  select(Month, Concession, Type, Cost)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tsibble: 816 x 4 [1M]
# Key:       Concession, Type [4]
      Month Concession   Type           Cost
      <mth> <chr>        <chr>         <dbl>

 2 1991 Aug Concessional Co-payments 1795733
 3 1991 Sep Concessional Co-payments 1777231
 4 1991 Oct Concessional Co-payments 1848507

```
:::

## Working with `tsibble` objects {-}
\fontsize{12}{14}\sf

We can use the `summarise()` function to summarise over keys.

\fontsize{8}{10}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/pbs4_5571f295ea9b91c776faffed7cbef328'}

```{.r .cell-code}
PBS |>
  filter(ATC2 == "A10") |>
  select(Month, Concession, Type, Cost) |>
  summarise(total_cost = sum(Cost))
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tsibble: 204 x 2 [1M]
      Month total_cost
      <mth>      <dbl>
 1 1991 Jul    3526591
 2 1991 Aug    3180891
 3 1991 Sep    3252221
 4 1991 Oct    3611003
 5 1991 Nov    3565869
 6 1991 Dec    4306371
 7 1992 Jan    5088335
 8 1992 Feb    2814520
 9 1992 Mar    2985811
10 1992 Apr    3204780
# i 194 more rows
```
:::
:::


## Working with `tsibble` objects {-}
\fontsize{12}{14}\sf

We can use the `mutate()` function to create new variables.

\fontsize{8}{10}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/pbs5_c13263ed669d697cd1196b94d9858107'}

```{.r .cell-code}
PBS |>
  filter(ATC2 == "A10") |>
  select(Month, Concession, Type, Cost) |>
  summarise(total_cost = sum(Cost)) |>
  mutate(total_cost = total_cost / 1e6)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tsibble: 204 x 2 [1M]
      Month total_cost
      <mth>      <dbl>
 1 1991 Jul       3.53
 2 1991 Aug       3.18
 3 1991 Sep       3.25
 4 1991 Oct       3.61
 5 1991 Nov       3.57
 6 1991 Dec       4.31
 7 1992 Jan       5.09
 8 1992 Feb       2.81
 9 1992 Mar       2.99
10 1992 Apr       3.20
# i 194 more rows
```
:::
:::


## Working with `tsibble` objects {-}
\fontsize{12}{14}\sf

We can use the `mutate()` function to create new variables.

\fontsize{8}{10}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/pbs6_a12879616e8cef7393d76ce408ac622c'}

```{.r .cell-code}
PBS |>
  filter(ATC2 == "A10") |>
  select(Month, Concession, Type, Cost) |>
  summarise(total_cost = sum(Cost)) |>
  mutate(total_cost = total_cost / 1e6) -> a10
```
:::

::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/a10_910afe616160678496e3cc893b4f0a7a'}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tsibble: 204 x 2 [1M]
      Month total_cost
      <mth>      <dbl>
 1 1991 Jul       3.53
 2 1991 Aug       3.18
 3 1991 Sep       3.25
 4 1991 Oct       3.61
 5 1991 Nov       3.57
 6 1991 Dec       4.31

10 1992 Apr       3.20

```
:::

# Lab Session 1

## Lab Session 1
\fontsize{14}{15}\sf

 1. Download [`tourism.xlsx`](http://robjhyndman.com/data/tourism.xlsx) from [`http://robjhyndman.com/data/tourism.xlsx`](http://robjhyndman.com/data/tourism.xlsx), and read it into R using `read_excel()` from the `readxl` package.
 2. Create a tsibble which is identical to the `tourism` tsibble from the `tsibble` package.
 3. Find what combination of `Region` and `Purpose` had the maximum number of overnight trips on average.
 4. Create a new tsibble which combines the Purposes and Regions, and just has total trips by State.

# Time plots
## Time plots
\fontsize{10}{11}\sf


::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/maxtemp_4b83978127653cd3c1488497fe760a17'}

```{.r .cell-code}
maxtemp <- vic_elec |>
  index_by(Day = date(Time)) |>
  summarise(Temperature = max(Temperature))
maxtemp |>
  autoplot(Temperature) +
  labs(y = "Max temperature")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](1-tsibbles_files/figure-beamer/maxtemp-1.pdf)
:::
:::

::: {.cell hash='1-tsibbles_cache/beamer/unnamed-chunk-5_5b69b816b39217f50c46be56705115e4'}
